conbody.p: Having a monadic PreparedSource value is so common, that is has its own data type:
conbody.codeblock: newtype Source m a = Source { genSource :: ResourceT m (PreparedSource m a) }
conbody.p: In fact, this is precisely why we refer to the original data type as a PreparedSource. We'll see later that the whole conduit package follows this naming pattern. We can easily wrap up our previous function with this newtype wrapper:
conbody.codeblock:
sourceList2 :: Resource m => [a] -> Source m a sourceList2 = Source . sourceList
sourceList :: Resource m => [a] -> ResourceT m (PreparedSource m a)
conbody.p: In addition to shorter type signatures, having a newtype allows us to write more appropriate instances. For example, we get a nice Functor instance:
conbody.codeblock:
sourceInts :: Resource m => Source m Int sourceInts = sourceList2 [1..10]
sourceStrings :: Resource m => Source m String sourceStrings = fmap show sourceInts
conbody.p: We also have a Monoid instance. What's important to note is that, the way this instance is implemented, any resource allocations occur as late as possible. For example, if you have a source that opens a file, reads its contents, and closes the file, and you mconcat five of those together, each file will be closed before the next one is open.
There's one more important instance- BufferSource. But that will have to wait until we cover resumable sources.
